questions.text: Which of the following secretions is NOT isotonic?
Which of the following statements about iron absorption is TRUE?

options.label: A
options.text: Iron absorption starts in the jejunum.

options.label: B
options.text: Phytic acid in cereals enhances iron absorption.

options.label: C
options.text: Ferrous (Fe²) form of iron is absorbed more readily than the ferric (Fe³) form.

options.label: D
options.text: Hepcidin directly binds to transferrin to regulate iron levels.

questions.correct_answer: C. Ferrous (Fe²) form of iron is absorbed more readily than the ferric (Fe³) form.

questions.text: Which vitamin is primarily absorbed in the ileum of the small intestine and requires an intrinsic factor for its absorption?
questions.explanation:
Type

Vitamin

Primary Absorption Site

Mechanism of Absorption

Fat-Soluble

A, D, E, K

(Options A and D)

 

Small intestine (Duodenum, mainly jejunum).
  • Require bile salts for emulsification.
  • Incorporated into mixed micelles.
  • Absorbed by passive diffusion into enterocytes.
  • Packaged into chylomicrons for transport.

Water-Soluble

B Vitamins

Jejunum and Ileum.

(B12 specifically in ileum)


 

Various mechanisms include:

  • Active transport
  • Passive diffusion
  • Carrier-mediated transport
  • Sodium-dependent transport
  • B12 requires an intrinsic factor

C (Option B)
  • Sodium-dependent active transport at low concentrations.
  • Passive diffusion at high concentrations.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the process of protein digestion?

options.label: A
options.text: Pepsin initiates the digestion of proteins in the small intestine.

options.label: B
options.text: Pepsin accounts for 90% of total protein digestion.

options.label: C
options.text: Collagen digestion starts in the small intestine.

options.label: D
options.text: The final step of protein digestion occurs inside the cytosol of Enterocytes.

questions.correct_answer: D. The final step of protein digestion occurs inside the cytosol of Enterocytes.

questions.text: A newborn presents with severe diarrhoea and dehydration shortly after birth. Stool analysis reveals undigested and unabsorbed carbohydrates. Which of the following mechanisms is most likely impaired in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: SGLT1-mediated absorption of glucose and galactose

questions.correct_answer: A. SGLT1-mediated absorption of glucose and galactose

questions.text: Which of the following intestinal cells are likely to have a high zinc concentration?

A 50-year-old patient with obstructive jaundice from a common bile duct stone, confirmed by elevated bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase, underwent successful stone extraction via ERCP. Post-procedure, the patient received education on bile flow regulation. Which of the following is not associated with bile synthesis?
questions.explanation:
Hormonal Regulation
  • Secretin (Option B): Stimulates the secretion of a watery, bicarbonate-rich solution by epithelial cells in the bile ducts.
  • Cholecystokinin (CCK): Induces gallbladder contraction and relaxation of the sphincter of Oddi, facilitating the release of concentrated bile into the duodenum in response to fatty foods.

Neural Regulation
  • Vagal Stimulation: Promotes weak gallbladder contraction.
  • Enteric Nervous System: Nerve fibres in the intestine stimulate gallbladder motility and secretion.

Feedback Regulation
  • It is influenced by the presence of fats and acids in the duodenum.
  • Bile salts are the most potent regulators of Bile synthesis, which is regulated by the feedback mechanism. (Option D)

questions.text: Which hormone is primarily responsible for stimulating the secretion of pancreatic digestive enzymes in response to the presence of peptides and fatty acids in the small intestine?

A 45-year-old male patient complains of frequent heartburn and bloating after meals, which worsens with large or spicy foods. He experiences relief with antacids, indicating excess gastric acid secretion. Which phase of gastric secretion is likely responsible for these symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Cephalic Phase
  • Trigger: Initiated by sensory stimuli such as sight, smell, thought, or taste of food.
  • Origin: Neurogenic signals originate in the cerebral cortex, amygdala, and hypothalamus and are transmitted via vagus nerves to stimulate gastric secretion.
  • Contribution: Accounts for approximately 30% of gastric secretion
  • Associated with meal anticipation and preparation.

Gastric Phase
  • Trigger: Begins when food enters the stomach.
  • Mechanisms:
    • Long vasovagal reflexes between the stomach and brain.
    • Local enteric reflexes within the stomach.
    • Gastrin release, which stimulates gastric juice secretion.
  • Duration: It lasts several hours while food remains in the stomach.
  • Contribution: Accounts for about 60% of total gastric secretion.

Intestinal phase
  • Trigger: Initiated by food reaching the duodenum of the small intestine.
  • Mechanism: Small amounts of gastrin released by duodenal mucosa continue to stimulate gastric juice secretion.
  • Contribution: Contributes to approximately 10% of the total acid response to a meal, ensuring continued digestive support as food progresses through the digestive tract.

questions.text: Which of the following factors is associated with increased gastric acid secretion?
questions.explanation:
Factors increasing gastric acid secretion

Factors inhibiting gastric acid secretion

Luminal
  • Peptides and amino acids.
  • Stomach distention

Acidic pH

Somatostatin (Option A)

Neural

Increased vagal discharge via GRP (Gastrin-Releasing Peptide)

–

Blood burn
  • Calcium
  • Epinephrine
  • Secretin (Option B)
  • GIP (Gastric Inhibitory Peptide)
  • VIP (Vasoactive Intestinal Peptide) Glucagon
  • Calcitonin (Option D).

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the mechanism of gastric acid secretion?

options.label: A
options.text: Release of K+ into the lumen by proton pump.

options.label: B
options.text: Secretion by the parietal cells in the stomach lining.

options.label: C
options.text: Intake of H+ by proton pump.

options.label: D
options.text: H+ and Cl- are released together into the lumen.

questions.correct_answer: B. Secretion by the parietal cells in the stomach lining.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female complains of excessive salivation irrespective of any sight or smell of food. Which of the following is true considering the autonomic regulation of salivary secretion?

options.label: A
options.text: Parasympathetic increases secretion, and Sympathetic decreases secretion.

options.label: B
options.text: Parasympathetic decreases secretion, and Sympathetic increases secretion.

options.label: C
options.text: Both Sympathetic and Parasympathetic increase secretion.

options.label: D
options.text: Both Sympathetic and Parasympathetic decrease secretion.

questions.correct_answer: C. Both Sympathetic and Parasympathetic increase secretion.
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Sympathetic System

Parasympathetic System

Salivary Secretion

Produces less saliva

Produces a larger volume of saliva.

Saliva Characteristics

Mucus-rich and thick.

Watery and less viscous.

Effect on Blood Vessels

No significant effect.

Dilates blood vessels, increasing gland nutrition

Saliva Composition

Less bicarbonate and K+

Higher concentrations of K+ and bicarbonate

Saliva Tonicity

Generally more viscous and less hypotonic.

Hypotonic

questions.text: Which cells in the duodenum and jejunum secrete the hormone that stimulates bile release and pancreatic enzyme secretion?
questions.explanation:
Hormone

Secreting Cells

Location

Function

CCK (Cholecystokinin)

I cells

(Option B)

Duodenum

Jejunum

Stimulates:

  • Pancreatic enzyme secretion
  • Pancreatic bicarbonate secretion
  • Gallbladder contraction (Release of bile)
  • Growth of exocrine pancreas

Inhibits:

  • Gastric emptying

Gastrin

G cells

(Option A)

Stomach (antrum) Duodenum

Stimulates:

  • Gastric acid secretion
  • Mucosal growth

Secretin

S cells

(Option C)

Duodenum

Stimulates:

  • Pepsin secretion
  • Pancreatic bicarbonate secretion
  • Biliary bicarbonate secretion
  • Growth of exocrine pancreas

Inhibits:

  • Gastrin release and gastric acid secretion

GIP (Glucose-dependent Insulinotropic Peptide)

K cells

(Option D)

Duodenum

Jejunum

Stimulates:

  • Insulin release from pancreatic β-cells
  • β-cell proliferation and survival
  • Glucose uptake in adipose tissue

Inhibits:

  • Gastric acid secretion
  • Gastric motility

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with symptoms of acid reflux and indigestion due to high acid content in her stomach. Which of the following is the most alkaline secretion in the GIT that can neutralise the acid content in her stomach?
questions.explanation:
Type of secretion

pH

Saliva

6.0-7.0 (Option C)

Gastric secretion

1.0-3.5 (Option D)

Pancreatic secretion

8.0-8.3 (Option B)

Bile

7.8

Small intestine secretion

7.5-8.0 (Option A)

Brunner’s gland secretion

8.0-8.9

Large intestinal secretion

7.5-8.0

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with acute diarrhoea after returning from a trip from southeast Asia. Laboratory tests confirm an infection with enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli (ETEC). Which of the following peptides is most likely influenced by this bacterial toxin?
Which of the following GI hormones is not responsible for insulin secretion?
questions.explanation:
HORMONE

STIMULI

CELLS

GIP (Gastric inhibitory peptide)

(A.k.a Glucose-dependent insulinotropic peptide)

Protein, Fats, Carbohydrates.


 

K cells of duodenum and jejunum.

Glucagon-like peptide

L cells in the small intestine.

CCK

Protein, Fats, Acid

I cells in duodenum and jejunum.

Gastrin

Protein, Gastric distension, Vagal stimulation

G cells in gastric antrum, duodenum and jejunum.

questions.text: A 52-year-old patient presents with symptoms of indigestion and steatorrhea. Laboratory tests suggest decreased bicarbonate secretion from the pancreas. Which Gastrointestinal hormone is most likely deficient in this patient?
Which of the following is NOT true regarding the effects of cholecystokinin on GI motility?
questions.correct_answer: B. Contraction of sphincter of Oddi

questions.text: Cholecystokinin (CCK) is a gastrointestinal hormone that acts on the pancreatic acinar cells to release all of the following except:
Which of the following is the primary stimulus for secretin release?

options.label: A
options.text: Fatty acids in the small intestine

options.label: B
options.text: Amino acids in the small intestine

questions.correct_answer: C. Acidic chyme entering the duodenum
questions.explanation:
Hormones

Stimuli

Secretin
  • Primary: Acidic chyme entering the duodenum (pH < 4.5)
  • Secondary:
    • Fatty acids in the duodenum
    • Peptides

Cholecystokinin

(CCK)
  • Partially digested proteins (peptides)
  • Fatty acids in the small intestine.
  • Amino acids in the small intestine.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents with fatigue, shortness of breath, and a sore tongue. Blood tests reveal macrocytic anaemia with low vitamin B12 levels. Further testing shows the presence of anti-intrinsic factor antibodies. What would you expect regarding this patient's serum gastrin levels?
Which of the following is NOT a primary function of a hormone responsible for gastric acid production?

options.label: C
options.text: Relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter

questions.correct_answer: C. Relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter
questions.explanation:
Gastric Secretion
  • Stimulates gastric acid secretion from parietal cells.
  • Promotes pepsinogen secretion from chief cells.

Gastric Motility

Enhances gastric motility and Promotes gastric emptying.

Trophic Effects

Stimulates growth and proliferation of gastric mucosa.

Sphincter Control

It causes contraction of the lower oesophagal sphincter (LES) and prevents reflux.

questions.text: Which of the following does NOT stimulate the secretion of Gastrin hormone?

options.label: A
options.text: Presence of proteins in the stomach

questions.correct_answer: D. Low pH in the stomach
questions.explanation:
Stimuli for Gastrin Release

Chemical Stimuli
  • Proteins and amino acids in the stomach (Option A)
  • Peptides
  • Calcium ions

Mechanical Stimuli
  • Distension of the stomach (Option C)

Neural Stimuli
  • Vagal nerve stimulation
  • Parasympathetic nervous system activation (Option B)

Other Factors
  • Caffeine
  • Alcohol
  • Certain medications (e.g., antacids)

Absence of Inhibitory Factors

  • Decreased acidity in the stomach (high pH)
